query: In a captive breeding program for Australian frogs, what are the most effective interventions to stimulate successful breeding?
relevant_summary: In captive breeding programs for Australian frogs, hormone treatment has been shown to be an effective intervention. One review and nine of 10 replicated studies in several countries, including Australia, found that hormone treatment of male amphibians stimulated or increased sperm production or resulted in successful breeding in captivity (883). For female amphibians, hormone treatment has had mixed results, with some studies showing that it stimulated egg production or successful breeding, while others found it did not (883). In addition to hormone treatment, environmental manipulations have also been found to be effective. The reproductive success of frogs in captivity has been found to depend on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season (835). Furthermore, providing a variety of substrates, such as rotting logs and hollow bamboo pipes, has been shown to promote egg-laying in frogs (1874). One Australian study also found success by temporarily flooding enclosures, manipulating sex ratios, and playing recorded mating calls (1874).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"In a captive breeding program for Australian frogs, what are the most effective interventions to stimulate successful breeding?"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "835",
  "action_title": "Captive breeding frogs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.
Twenty-three of 33 studies, three of which were reviews and 30 replicated studies, across the world found that amphibians produced egg in captivity, in four cases by captive-bred females. Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One found that froglet survival was low and another that three species were not successfully raised to adulthood.
Four replicated studies (including one small study) in,Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong and Italy found that 30–88% of eggs hatched or survival to metamorphosis was 75%, as froglets was 17–51% or to adults was 50–90% in captivity.
One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."
}

query: What are the documented effects of modifying captive primate diets to better reflect what they would eat in the wild?
relevant_summary: One study in the UK found that providing a fruit-free diet to lemurs led to a decrease in aggression and self-directed behaviour [1329]. In the USA, a study on gorillas found that substituting milk with fruit juice resulted in a reduction in regurgitation and reingestion [1329]. Another study in the USA involving rhesus macaques showed that offering fresh produce instead of pellet feed increased the time spent feeding and reduced inactivity [1335]. In two separate studies in Japan and the USA, increasing the number of daily feeds for chimpanzees led to more time spent feeding, but it also increased the incidence of hair eating in baboons [1337].

query: For captive carnivores, how does the effectiveness of hiding or scattering food compare to simply changing its location within the enclosure?
relevant_summary: Hiding food around an enclosure was found in five studies to increase exploring and foraging behaviors in black bears, leopard cats, bush dogs, maned wolves, and Malayan sun bears (1915). Two of these studies also found a decrease in stereotypical pacing in leopard cats and black bears (1915). Another study found that hiding food reduced the time Canadian lynx spent sleeping during the day (1915). One study in Brazil found that scattering food increased locomotion in maned wolves and that they spent more time in the area with scattered food compared to food on a tray (1921). A study in Ireland on cheetahs found that altering the location of food decreased pacing behaviors (1918).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effectiveness of food enrichment for captive carnivores"}

query: What is the state of evidence on presenting food that encourages or requires tool use in captive primates?
relevant_summary: There is no evidence for the effects of presenting food to primates that requires the use or modification of tools (1319). However, two before-and-after studies in the USA and the UK found that using puzzle feeders increased tool use, foraging behavior, and aggression, but decreased food sharing (1318). A replicated, before-and-after study in the USA also found that puzzle feeders led to more time spent feeding and less inactivity (1318). Another replicated, before-and-after study in the USA found that primates were more active and increased their tool use when food was presented in water-filled troughs (1320).

query: For captive felids, what are some effective alternatives to presenting food frozen in ice for reducing stereotypic behaviours?
relevant_summary: The provision of bones, hides, or partial carcasses has been shown to be effective in reducing stereotypic behaviors in some captive felids. One study found that providing bones decreased the frequency of stereotypic behaviors in lions and tigers (1902). Additionally, providing bones was found to increase activity and manipulation time in felids (1902). Hiding food around the enclosure is another strategy that has been shown to be effective. One study found that hiding food decreased stereotypical pacing in leopard cats (1915). This method has also been found to increase exploring and foraging behaviors (1915).

relevant_summary: No evidence was found for the effects of presenting food to primates that requires the use or modification of tools (1319). This means that no studies that directly and quantitatively tested this action have been found (1319).

query: For improving the diet of captive primates, how does presenting whole foods instead of processed compare to providing fresh produce instead of pellets?
relevant_summary: A before-and-after study in the USA on macaques showed that presenting whole foods instead of chopped foods led to an increase in the amount of food consumed and the time spent feeding (1323). In a separate replicated, before-and-after study in the USA, it was found that providing fresh produce instead of pellet feed to rhesus macaques resulted in more time spent feeding and less time being inactive (1335).

query: In a European zoo setting, what actions are available to simulate seasonal environmental changes to encourage breeding in captive amphibians?
relevant_summary: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in Germany and Austria found that simulating a wet and dry season using artificial rainfall, as well as moving amphibians to an enclosure with more egg laying sites and flowing water in Austria, stimulated breeding and egg deposition (1872). In the German study, no toadlets survived past 142 days old (1872). No evidence was found for the effects of varying enclosure humidity with humidifiers, foggers/misters, or artificial rain (1863), or for varying the duration of enclosure lighting to simulate seasonal changes in the wild (1866).

query: What are the observed behavioural and physiological outcomes of feeding captive primates a diet that more closely reflects their natural nutritional composition?
relevant_summary: One before-and-after study in the USA found that when gorilla diets had milk replaced with fruit juice, there was a decrease in regurgitation and reingestion (1329). A replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that lemurs fed a fruit-free diet exhibited lower levels of aggression and self-directed behaviour (1329). In a replicated, before-and-after study in the USA, rhesus macaques that were given fresh produce instead of pellet feed spent more time feeding and less time inactive (1335). No evidence was found for the effects of providing nectar to primates (1331).

query: What are the trade-offs involved when feeding whole carcasses to captive carnivores?
relevant_summary: Two replicated, before-and-after studies in the USA found that feeding whole carcasses reduced pacing levels in lions, leopards, snow leopards and cougars, but increased pacing in tigers (1901). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Denmark found that cheetahs fed whole rabbit had lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A levels compared to supplemented beef (1901). One replicated before-and-after study in Denmark found that feeding whole rabbit showed lower levels of inflammatory bowel indicators in cheetahs (1901). One replicated, randomized study and one controlled study in the USA found that when fed whole 1 to 3 day old chickens, ocelots had lower digestible energy and fat compared to a commercial diet and African wildcats had had lower organic matter digestibility compared to a ground-chicken diet (1901). One before-and-after study in the USA found that hunting behaviour increased and sleeping decreased when a fishing cat was provided with live fish (1925).

One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Denmark found that cheetahs fed whole rabbit had lower blood protein urea, zinc and vitamin A levels compared to supplemented beef (1901). query: To improve the welfare of captive maned wolves, what are the most effective dietary and food presentation interventions documented?
relevant_summary: For captive maned wolves, a plant-derived protein diet was found to increase digestible energy and dry matter digestibility, but it also led to decreased mineral retention and plasma taurine levels when compared to an animal-based protein diet (1903). Providing a commercial diet resulted in similar dry matter intake and digestibility, despite a lower protein content (1900). Supplementing an animal-protein diet with taurine was found to increase plasma taurine levels (1908). In terms of food presentation, scattering food was found to increase locomotion in maned wolves, and they spent more time in the area of their enclosure with the scattered food (1921). Hiding food around the enclosure increased exploring and foraging behaviors in maned wolves and other carnivores (1915).
